methodology.title: Methodology
methodology.subtitle: How our presidential election forecast model works
methodology.challenge: The Challenge of Forecasting Presidential Elections
methodology.overviewDescription: We've developed a Bayesian statistical model to forecast Portuguese presidential elections. The model combines polling data with candidate party affiliations, adjusting for pollster house effects and quantifying uncertainty through Monte Carlo simulations.
methodology.challengeDescription1: Portuguese presidential elections use a two-round system. If no candidate receives more than 50% of the vote in the first round, the top two candidates proceed to a runoff. With multiple candidates and a significant percentage of undecided voters, forecasting outcomes requires carefully modeling uncertainty.
methodology.challengeList2: Candidates with varying levels of public recognition
methodology.challengeList3: Campaign dynamics that can shift rapidly
methodology.modelDescription: Our approach uses a hierarchical Bayesian model to estimate the evolution of support for each candidate over time. This allows us to capture both smooth trends and sudden shifts while always quantifying uncertainty.
methodology.component1Desc: We model the underlying support for each candidate using polling data
methodology.component2Desc: We account for systematic biases in different polling organizations
methodology.component3Desc: We incorporate priors based on the parties supporting each candidate
methodology.component4Desc: We run thousands of simulations to calculate win probabilities
methodology.pollingCollect: We collect polling data from major Portuguese polling organizations and apply several corrections:
methodology.pollingHouseEffectsDesc: Each pollster has systematic tendencies to over- or under-estimate certain candidates
methodology.pollingRecencyDesc: More recent polls have greater influence
methodology.pollingModeDesc: We account for differences between online, telephone, and in-person polling
methodology.simulationDesc: For each simulation, we generate vote shares for each candidate and check:
methodology.simulationStep1: Whether any candidate reaches more than 50% in the first round
methodology.simulationStep2: Which two candidates advance to the second round
methodology.simulationStep3: Record the outcome of each simulation
methodology.simulationConclusion: We run thousands of these simulations to build probability distributions for outcomes.
methodology.uncertaintyDesc: Our model incorporates several sources of uncertainty:
methodology.uncertaintyPollingDesc: Historical polling accuracy in Portuguese elections
methodology.uncertaintyCampaignDesc: Potential for late shifts in voter preference
methodology.uncertaintyUndecidedDesc: Significant uncertainty about how undecided voters will vote
methodology.validationStep1: Backtesting on previous Portuguese presidential elections
methodology.validationStep4: Calibration tests to ensure our probabilities are well-calibrated
methodology.validationDescription: We continuously refine our model based on these validation exercises.
methodology.limitationsDescription1: Our model has several important limitations:
methodology.limitationsList1: Relies on polling data, which can be biased or unrepresentative
methodology.limitationsList2: May not capture unprecedented political developments
methodology.limitationsList3: Assumes historical patterns continue to hold
methodology.limitationsList4: Cannot predict the impact of major campaign events or scandals
methodology.limitationsList5: Difficulty predicting how undecided voters will behave
methodology.limitationsDescription2: We encourage users to interpret our forecasts as probabilistic estimates, not certainties.
methodology.dataSourcesList1: Portuguese polling organizations (CESOP, Aximage, Pitagórica, Intercampus, etc.)
methodology.dataSourcesList2: Previous presidential election results from CNE
methodology.dataSourcesList3: Demographic data from INE (Instituto Nacional de Estatística)

presidential.spaghettiDescription: Each line represents one possible simulation outcome. The spread of lines shows the uncertainty in our forecast - with ~35% undecided voters, outcomes remain highly uncertain.
presidential.trendDescription: Estimated support over time for the top candidates. Lines show the mean estimate, shaded bands show 50% and 95% credible intervals. Dots represent individual polls.
presidential.modelDescription: This forecast uses a Bayesian model that combines polling data with candidate-specific priors based on party affiliation. The model accounts for pollster house effects and uncertainty in voter preferences.
presidential.undecidedWarning: Important: Approximately 35% of voters remain undecided. This forecast shows declared voting intention only - actual results may differ significantly as undecided voters make their choices.
presidential.factor2: Candidate party affiliations and historical patterns
presidential.aboutDescription: Portuguese presidential elections use a two-round system. If no candidate receives more than 50% of votes in the first round, the top two candidates proceed to a second round. This forecast models declared voting intention based on available polling data.
presidential.runoffScenariosDescription: With a second round nearly certain, these are the most likely candidate matchups based on our simulations.
